docs.snippet: The large United States delegation to the world trade talks that begin in Brussels next week expects a lot of hard fights and maneuvering -- and when that's done it will have to sit down and negotiate with other countries.    None of the other 106...
docs.lead_paragraph: The large United States delegation to the world trade talks that begin in Brussels next week expects a lot of hard fights and maneuvering -- and when that's done it will have to sit down and negotiate with other countries. None of the other 106 nations at the talks will have to reconcile so many conflicting views within its own negotiating team, and none of the other delegations is likely to wash so much dirty laundry in public.

headline.main: U.S. Trade Team: 'A Kind of Stew'

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: President Bush leaves on a weeklong tour of South America on Sunday intended to further his efforts to create a hemispheric free-trade zone and demonstrate interest in a continent long forsaken by United States Presidents.   Administration officials...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush leaves on a weeklong tour of South America on Sunday intended to further his efforts to create a hemispheric free-trade zone and demonstrate interest in a continent long forsaken by United States Presidents. Administration officials said they did not expect any major agreements to come out of Mr. Bush's trip to Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and Venezuela. But they said that along with economic matters a broad range of items would be discussed, including protection of the Amazon jungle, nuclear nonproliferation and the continuing instability in Central America.

headline.main: Bush to Press Trade on South American Trip

byline.original: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONDAY: GATT talks in Brussels to conclude the Uruguay Round, through Dec. 7. * Construction spending for October. * Purchasing managers' survey for November.  TUESDAY: Oral arguments scheduled in New York on temporary order barring Donald Trump from...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONDAY: GATT talks in Brussels to conclude the Uruguay Round, through Dec. 7. * Construction spending for October. * Purchasing managers' survey for November. TUESDAY: Oral arguments scheduled in New York on temporary order barring Donald Trump from selling his houses. * November auto sales. * October new home sales. WEDNESDAY: Factory orders for October. * Third-quarter labor productivity and costs. * The Center for Financial Engineering in Development hosts a conference in Washington on the prospects for American business in Vietnam. THURSDAY: Major retailers report November sales. FRIDAY: Unemployment for November. * Consumer credit for October. * Annual meeting of Carter Hawley Hale.

docs.snippet: Canada, Japan, Sweden and Switzerland will propose new rules to broaden world trade in international banking and other financial services when world trade talks open here on Monday.    Japan's involvement in the proposal is highly significant because...
docs.lead_paragraph: Canada, Japan, Sweden and Switzerland will propose new rules to broaden world trade in international banking and other financial services when world trade talks open here on Monday. Japan's involvement in the proposal is highly significant because it is the first time Japan has taken a leadership position in the trade negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round because they started in that nation in 1986.

headline.main: Progress Shown On Bank Rules At Trade Talks

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: With the shadow of failure hanging over the global trade talks that begin in Brussels on Monday, Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is all too aware that he can neither take sides nor impose solutions....
docs.lead_paragraph: With the shadow of failure hanging over the global trade talks that begin in Brussels on Monday, Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is all too aware that he can neither take sides nor impose solutions. "All I can do is to put them at a table and make them negotiate," he said. After four years of the current round of trade talks, real negotiations -- in the sense of tit-for-tat concessions between major trading blocs on issues like agriculture, services and textiles -- have been left to the final hour.

headline.main: Top Official at GATT Faces a Round in Crisis

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: President Bush began a six-day trip through Latin America intended to show support for strapped democracies today, telling Brazil's Congress that it is time "to end the false distinctions between the first world and third world that have too long...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush began a six-day trip through Latin America intended to show support for strapped democracies today, telling Brazil's Congress that it is time "to end the false distinctions between the first world and third world that have too long limited political and economic relations in the Americas." But even as Mr. Bush spoke of helping Latin America enjoy a "new dawn in the New World," a coup attempt in Argentina overshadowed the beginning of the trip, causing White House advisers to worry that President Bush might have to cancel his visit to Argentina. But they insisted all day that the Argentine President, Carlos Saul Menem, would bring things under control and that the trip was on.

headline.main: Bush Begins His Latin Tour in Brazil Amid Worry Over Argentina Strife

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT

byline.original: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: At the end of the first day of a pivotal week of talks to liberalize world trade, fears grew that a continuing stalemate in negotiations on farm trade could lead to a collapse of the negotiations.   After two hours of talks on agricultural trade...
docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of the first day of a pivotal week of talks to liberalize world trade, fears grew that a continuing stalemate in negotiations on farm trade could lead to a collapse of the negotiations. After two hours of talks on agricultural trade ended tonight, officials from the United States and several other farm-exporting countries voiced dismay about the European Community's failure to make concessions to reduce protection to farmers.

headline.main: At Trade Talks, Fear of Collapse

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: This week's conference involving more than 100 countries may be the biggest trade game in the world, but it is not the only one.    The United States, Canada and Mexico have just concluded important talks in this city on coming negotiations to shape...
docs.lead_paragraph: This week's conference involving more than 100 countries may be the biggest trade game in the world, but it is not the only one. The United States, Canada and Mexico have just concluded important talks in this city on coming negotiations to shape a North American common market. And President Bush is visiting Latin America to promote trade agreements.

headline.main: Brussels Talks Not the Only Trade Game Around

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: President Bush, on the second stop of his Latin American tour, gave a strong pledge today to relieve the economic burden that small countries face from rising oil prices in connection with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.    Mr. Bush warned: "I can make...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush, on the second stop of his Latin American tour, gave a strong pledge today to relieve the economic burden that small countries face from rising oil prices in connection with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Mr. Bush warned: "I can make clear that this is not going to go on forever. And it is not going to go on forever."

headline.main: BUSH, IN URUGUAY, VOWS OIL PRICE AID

byline.original: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: President Bush has started his five-nation tour of South America speaking of democracy. His Latin hosts, all democratically elected presidents, are talking of debt.     "To fulfill the New World's destiny, all of the Americas and the Caribbean must...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush has started his five-nation tour of South America speaking of democracy. His Latin hosts, all democratically elected presidents, are talking of debt. "To fulfill the New World's destiny, all of the Americas and the Caribbean must embark on a venture for the coming century: to create the first fully democratic hemisphere in the history of mankind," Mr. Bush said on Monday as he began the first tour of South America by an American president in eight years.

byline.original: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times
